advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1989</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special 520-STFM bundle advert.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There's no catch. We're giving you the Atari 520 STFM and £500 worth of great software titles for just £399.99.<br> The twenty-three super titles include some of the greatest games and three excellent programs which introduce you to the BASIC programming language, computer-created music and the more popular computer applications such as word processing and spreadsheets...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special Christmas offer with 12 games.<br><br> Monochrome version: <b>£199</b><br> Colour version: <b>£299</b><br></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> £99 IN JANUARY 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ABORTED ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the aborted advert campaigns for the 8048 was "Micromania".<p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 Hannover show advert. <br><br> Advert said that 30,000 Kaypro II systems were already sold in the U.S.A.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You hesitate between two standards."<br> "Rank Xerox doesn't."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> SEGA'S new hard keyboard and new hard disk drive, make Sega even harder to beat.<br> The very latest industry standard 3" diskettes store a massive 328K of information each desk, and operate at speeds far in excess of their older 5 1/4 inch counterparts. Sega's super control station will also enable you to connect to many other attachments such as business printers electronic typewriters even telephone moderns, through it's two additional I/0 ports, for RS232C and parallel interfaces. <br><br> Sega now boasts not only the most sophisticated and easy to learn basic language, the most incredible graphic capabilities, a sensational range of cartridge and cassette games, superb education and applications software written by and for New Zealanders, but also a very sophisticated, fast, small business system, with the state of the art Sega control station. Feel the difference, see the difference, compare the difference, and you too can enjoy the difference of Sega superiority.</font> <br><br> Notice that between numerous superlatives, the advertising agency mistook floppy disk for hard disk drive.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 100 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>German advert for the Philips Odyssey 200 model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dieterkoenig.at/ccc/" target="_blank">Dieter Koening</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Large achievement capability and high versatility with 64kb RAM." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MENTA & SOFTY ADVERT (FRANCE, SEPT. 82)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGA POSTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>New version with Shugart 360 KB formatted capacity floppy drives. Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">North Star has quadrupled the disk capacity of the Horizon computer but prices have increased a modest 15 percent. On a dollar per byte basis, that's a bargain that is hard to beat!...</font><br><br> 1979 prices for assembled versions including 32KB RAM, one parallel and two serial I/O ports:<br> 1 F.D. version: <b>$2565</b><br> 2 F.D. version: <b>$3215</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The Sinclair Phenomenon"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (MAR. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> The electric typewriter's days are numbered. Because now there's a machine that put real wordprocessing power within everyone's reach.<br> The Amstrad PCW 8256 is a complete word-processor and a powerful computer in one unit.<br> And it's unbelievably low price includes a screen with built-in disc drive, keyboard, printer and word processing software...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE LOGO (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple Logo was a very successful implementation of Logo. It contained some advanced features such as property list and packages, as well as extremely good documentation.<br><br> At the time, Apple thought the Logo language would encourage schools to invest heavily in personal computers for all the class levels.<br> Sadly, Logo never became the revolutionary language that they had hoped for and very few schools taught it to their pupils (except in France).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE PERSONABLE COMPUTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What's a personable computer? It's a computer with business application versatility at personal computer price. It's a computer powerful enough to tackle even your toughest business jobs, yet at a price that wont put you out of business...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://wotsit.thingy.com/haj/">Howard Jones</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

computer.description: In 1978, the Sharp parts division, in charge of semiconductor sales, became one of the first second source distributor of Zilog CIE. In order to promote the LH-0080 (Sharp Z80) and associated chips, the division thought up and sold two training cards based on the LH-0080 processor and the LH-0081 PIO chip. These two cards were the SM-B-80TE and the SM-B-80TC. The major difference between these two models is the keyboard that is here separated from the main board. Still, the keys and display arrangements are exactly the same as the 80TE. It could also be connected to the 80TE system. Programs entered could be recorded on a cassette tape. A a second I/O connector, managed by a Sharp Z80 PIO allowed the user to connect peripheral devices like a printer. The board could be a part of a larger computer made of several cards mounted onto a backplane due to a second large 100-pin connector (S-100?). Thanks to Ohishi Nuboaki and his Sharp MZ dedicated
computer.keyboard: Mechanical 25 keys - Hexadecimal and function keys
computer.name: SM-B-80TC
computer.ports: 100-pin expansion connector, 2 x Z80 PIO interface connectors
computer.ram: 1 KB static RAM expandable to 3 KB (2114 chips)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> THE BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote>Japanese box.<br> It seems that the system was never sold outside Japan.</blockquote>
